>>91473365
You will never be a real display server. You have no hardware cursors, you have no xrandr, you have no setxkbmap. You are a toy project twisted by Red Hat and GNOME into a crude mockery of X11’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your developers are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “users” laugh at your lack of features behind closed doors.

Linux users are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed them to sniff out defective software with incredible efficiency. Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The best beginner distro is the one you choose to try Linux first on. If you want to learn Linux quickly I unironically recommend Gentoo, since you will very quickly learn how to do common tasks from CLI just by following the Handbook.

If your goal isn't to "learn Linux", mint is fine if you don't care about how you are going to upgrade in a year, and Mint/PopOS/Ubuntu will enable a lot of bad habits that will bite your ass down the line like adding external repos, sudo make install, running github scripts etc that Debian users know are bad ideas.

Debian is a good beginner distro if you read the handbook beforehand and go in with an open mind. Nowadays when I introduce my friends to Linux it's less "Is this person technically minded?" When deciding which Distro for them but more "Does this person have an open-mind to learn how to do things differently" when deciding Mint vs Debian.

honestly this kind of thing is so trivial I would this kind of thing on the fly with bash and not even remember I did it. But to translate OP's script into python would look something like this:

import os
import subprocess as sp
import shutil

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', os.getcwd())
minbitrate = os.getenv('minbitrate', '2500k')
maxbitrate = os.getenv('maxbitrate', '5000k')

ffmpeg = shutil.which('ffpmeg')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):
    if fname.endswith('.avs'):
        newname = fname[:-4] + '.mp4'
        arglist = ['-i', fname, '-c:v',
                   #etc
                   minbitrate, '-maxrate:v', maxbitrate,
                   #etc
                   newname]
        print(' '.join(arglist))
        sp.call([ffmpeg] + arglist)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91475926
fixed path
import os
import subprocess as sp
import shutil

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', os.getcwd())
minbitrate = os.getenv('minbitrate', '2500k')
maxbitrate = os.getenv('maxbitrate', '5000k')

ffmpeg = shutil.which('ffpmeg')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):
    if fname.endswith('.avs'):
        oldname = os.path.join(in_dir, fname)
        newname = oldname[:-4] + '.mp4'
        arglist = ['-i', oldname, '-c:v',
                   #etc
                   minbitrate, '-maxrate:v', maxbitrate,
                   #etc
                   newname]
        print(' '.join(arglist))
        sp.call([ffmpeg] + arglist)

Powershell is not a shell unto itself, but rather another proprietary component of a sometimes functioning Windows system made useful by the win32api corelibs, telemetry utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by a myriad of competing and contradicting "standards".
Many computer users run a modified version of the win32api system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of win32api which is widely used today is often called “Powershell”, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the win32api system, developed by Microsoft. There really is a Powershell, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use.

posts.com:
This is how I'd write it in POSIX shell which is a subset of bash so I suppose it still applies. It's mainly bikeshedding here so I don't see the point but you are very deluded if you think that []:: soup looks better than simply ``basename file suffix''.
for vid in $0/*.avs; do
    ffmpeg -i "$vid" \
        -c:v h264_nvenc -rc:v vbr_hq \
        -cq:v 19 -b:v "$1" -maxrate:v "$2" \
        -preset llhq -profile:v high \
        "$(basename "$vid" .avs).mp4"
done

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import subprocess

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', '.')
min_bitrate = os.getenv('min_bitrate', '2500k')
max_bitrate = os.getenv('max_bitrate', '5000k')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):
    fname_no_ext, fname_ext = os.path.splitext(fname)
    if fname.endswith('.avs'):
        old_path = os.path.join(in_dir, fname)
        new_path = os.path.join(in_dir, fname_no_ext + '.mp4')
        subprocess.run([
            'ffmpeg', '-i', old_path,
            '-c:v', min_bitrate, '-maxrate:v', max_bitrate,
            new_path])

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91472172
sudoedit doesn't just run the editor as root, that'd be hilariously insecure. It runs your editor on a temporary file, then it writes that temp file to the actual file. You need to go out of your way to mess that up. And sudo does.
What sudoedit does (see src/sudo_edit.c and plugins/sudoers/editor.c, correct me if I'm wrong) is take your $EDITOR, append --, append the files to edit, and then later read back from that by looking for -- in order to remember which files to edit.
So if you insert your own -- it finds your -- instead of the -- it added itself. It's not just unsanitized input, it's in-band signaling.
The right thing to do would have been to keep the editor and the file list separate until the very last minute. (Instead they slapped on the band-aid fix you describe. Which was reasonable under the circumstances.)
This smells like somebody tried to avoid allocating a whole other buffer out of laziness. In higher-level languages doing it right would have been less inconvenient.

wait...
but `editor` does not operate as root

what `sudoedit` does is:
1. copy the given file to a /var/tmp/file.xyz location
2. run "$EDITOR /var/tmp/file.xyz" *AS USER, NOT ROOT*
3. after editing, move /var/tmp/file.xyz back to original location

setting EDITOR to "vi -- /etc/passwd" makes it call:
"vi -- /etc/passwd /var/tmp/file.xyz"
so, yes, you are editing /etc/passwd, but AS USER!
and then unchanged /var/tmp/file.xyz is moved back

literally not a security issue at all

It runs the editor as yourself, on a temporary file. It doesn't run the editor as root. It doesn't give the editor direct access to the file.
There's no reason $EDITOR needs to be trusted at all, unless you're doing something very strange.

That's what you'd think, but sudoedit does something really inane under the hood. See >>91472442.
When you run 
EDITOR='vi -- /etc/passwd' file.xyz
it validates that you're allowed to edit file.xyz, then it creates an array 
"vi" "--" "/etcpasswd" "--" "file.xyz"
, then it scans for the 
"--"
it just inserted and assumes that all the strings after that are files you're allowed to edit, and only then does it start creating temporary files.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91472831
You are not understanding what is _actually_ going on under the hood.
`sudoedit` is NOT a separate binary, it's a symlink to sudo
You're imagining that they are separate, modular binaries, they are not.
sudo has to parse it's command line arguments, and then decide what to do with it. It inspects argv[0] to decide what subaction to take.
In order to contextualize the arguments to know what to do with it, sudo must parse it's input. As a consequence it has to identify the files and editor command separately from the command line.
That's why your suggestion is not correct, sudo could just as easily identify files (to write with root permission) from $EDITOR if its not careful.
Because it's the same binary and same codebase as visudo, it NEEDS to do some parsing to keep it secure.
Hence why it makes no sense to keep the argument vector separate, and a keyword is a sensible solution.
You can argue that perhaps sudoedit and visudo should be their own binaries, sure. Then your solution makes *some* sense.
You can also argue that perhaps it shouldn't open anything at all in $EDITOR with root, even with visudo - allowing you to keep $EDITOR and argv separate - but this breaks some workflows and features.

The editor doesn't execute as root. If it did then all security would be lost automatically. The editor executes with your privileges on a tempfile.

The problem is internal bookkeeping gone wrong. It merges $EDITOR and the files you want to edit into one array (before making tempfiles), then gets confused about where one starts and the other begins.

>>91481975

I calculated it on my own a few years ago, it goes something like this, which is still a vast simplication:

1) A neuron A has an electrical field F(q, r) where F is the force of the electrical field depending on A's charge the position in the field given by a vector r.

2) The electric field F(q,r) influences the (possibly moving) charges of all A_i

3) In turn, the charges of all A_i have an influence on A and thus on F(q, r)

Why are the elelctrical fields important at all? Because neurons communicate by chemical transmission and ion channels.

So to know the firing behaviour of a single neuron A, you have to solve A's partial DGL, which commonly does not have a analytic solution but only an, often times highly expensive, numerical solution.

It's not quite as bad as the 16 coupled partial differential equations describing spacetime in GR but still incredibly expensive to calculate.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_potential


If I find the time, I will redo the calc + post on github + link on the AI assistant channel here.

>currently the two wlan router have their own wifi network but i want to combine them into one so that you dont have to manually switch the network on the phone or whatever.
Not sure what you mean by network in this context. A separate IP network? So the extra one is in router mode? Switch it to access point mode so you'll be having one single Ethernet block.
Network as in the name the WiFi has? Yes, you can name both the same and set the same password.
>mesh
>WDS
Forget all that, it's not relevant to you as they are on the same wired backbone.
>i still have either two separately named SSIDs that i can connect to or i name them the same resulting in the old router just disappearing.
They are separate access points no matter what, you can't magically make the two boxes appear as one.
You can keep adding more of them if the coverage is not good enough, that's what they do in enterprise environments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91479692
Both are more or less correct, don't get lost on the all the POO buzzwords.
I'll address the part I think you're caught up on: Objects don't have names, they're just values located somewhere in memory. A variable references that location -- you can have more than one variable reference the same object. Still, if you call "scans" an "object of the Scanner class" it's still perfectly idiomatic and nobody will think you're crazy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91473504
The high conductivity on the Z axis (between the CPU and heatsink) makes up for the lackluster contact.
The graphite pads also have the quirk of having super insane conductivity on the X/Y plane, this means any heat going into the pad is spread across the pad. Heat up one edge and it will damn near instantly transfer the heat to the other edge.

This all sounds like it should be better than paste but like you said psate is just so good at filling voids and pads aren't very good.

In some cases those graphite pads can be better. I used to use Artic MX-2 but got cooler temps with the IC graphite.

there's a few reasons why people don't get their shit straight from china, the first being that chinese sellers are really closed off for the average consumer. If you don't know how to speak chinese, you won't be able to talk to the the vast majority of the sellers. There's also security. For what it's worth, alibaba/aliexpress policy is not really enforceable and you can often get ripped off, whereas with Amazon it's really easy to ask for a refund/cheat the system. There's also shipping time.

the $2.5 USD exemple you gave can only be possible because of theft so you could effectively put any price you wanted on that drive, the result would be the same, and that price wouldn't be possible with a big enough volume of sale. However there IS a markup on what we have available on western websites, and it's (in part) caused by greed as you said. But there's also the fact that you need to store the goods, pay taxes, ship the items and pay the people that work in that chain.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91456858
>Uh. Maybe I'll try that later.
It's remarkably simple, all you really need, espeically for smaller sized racks, is four rack posts, a floor and top (both mounted the same way), and then two bits of aluminium or steel angle for each post

I hope this diagram makes sense. you are just attaching the rack posts to the angle, and then having the angle rest on the floor. all of this is done purely to stop it from moving - the steel rack posts will handle 100% of the weight anyway, you just need them to not move. since 100% of the force on the rack is straight down, you don't really need a lot of sideways enforcement; unless you knock it over it won't ever sheer.

And while I say the wood cladding is purely decorative, it also serves as an attachment point for front-to-back cross bracing, which isn't strictly necessary but it helps reduce some wobble with a half-full rack. really, your equipment provides 80% of the structural rigidity anyway

>>91463141
If you have CF proxying enabled, your SSL certs don't matter because CF does MiTM attack (decrypt traffic) and reencrypts your data with their own certs before it reaches the client. If your most important intention is to obscure your origin IP, and you use CF proxy for that, I see no point in having a server not "protected". If you want to add a server as a failover that will work even if CF goes down, obviously don't use their proxying for that server.
As long as you don't host stuff that can make people mad at you (e.g. kiwis), I don't think it's necessary to accept a persistent MiTM "attack" that's required for their proxy to work.
>And would running certbot on the failover server cause issues?
You might want to switch to DNS-01 challenge, because HTTP-01 will cause the validation servers to ask your primary nginx for verification, and it won't have it setup because certbot is on failover. Or you could have a post-renewal hook on main server to push updated certs to the other box.

>>91472566
as the other guy (and... that thing) said, RAID isn't a requirement
it's nice to have and costs you very little if using raid5 (aka raidz1) but the important thing to note is that
>RAID protects you from DOWNTIME
>BACKUPS protect you from DATA LOSS
if you don't need 100% uptime, RAID isn't going to do much for you. you should have all your important data backed up in at least one place, and updated regularly, at least once a day.
the reason RAID isn't a backup is because if you delete a file, have corrupted files, get a virus, etc, RAID will replicate those changes as they happen, whereas with a daily backup, you have at least a day to notice the problem and solve it. if a day isn't long enough, then set up a daily and a weekly backup; the daily so you can restore up-to-date data, and the weekly so you will have a full week to react if needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91472950
>People take the "RAID is not a backup" thing way too far.
not really. there are plenty of people that set up a raid1 and think it will protect them from things like ransomware (which is actually the most common cause of data loss, statistically speaking, closely followed by human error/accidental deletion)

RAID only protects against one, very specific type of failure - the drive, which unless you are buying used drives, is very uncommon - in most situations by the time your drive is reaching it's EoL, you are looking to upgrade anyway because your data grows over time and HDDs are projected to last a minimum of five years of constant use.
yes, RAID is still useful, I use raidz2 on all my servers. but it's not even close to being an adequate backup solution because drive failure is probably the least common cause of data loss, contrary to what you seem to believe.

>>91473336
you can use raid if you like, but you do have to understand what it does and why it's used. you should absolutely not expect raid1 or raid5 to protect you from data loss, ever, because it won't. I can almost guarantee you that you will not have a HDD fail before you buy new ones. protection from an accidental "rm -rf" or a virus, or any other of the most common causes for data loss is what you really *need*, RAID is just an optional thing for increases uptime.

the only reason I didn't bring this up is it requires having at least double the storage space for backup, if not more. yes it is the ideal solution for backups, but it's also the most expensive.
in most situations you can get away with a single, daily backup. preferably you would have 2x the space for backups and do one weekly and one daily, both stored on separate devices. In a perfect setup, you would have 3-2-1 with one being off-site, but for most people this isn't practical or affordable. I mean, I'm sitting on nearly 100TB of data, so I have 200TB of pure backup space for my weekly and daily backups. to do incremental ones I'd need closer to 300 or even 400TB if you include an offsite

>>91474526
maybe not doubke, but it still needs extra space for all the revisions. if you din't change files often, it's not much, but it's good to budget double for the sake of ensuring file integrity in case of an unknown issue. if you get hit with ransomware and it backs that up, you need space for all of those changed files' new revision

if you aren't leaving space for that you've basicallt defeated the entire point. it's still more beneficial that not having a backup, but you might as well not bother with increments unless you budget space for a full revision of every file, ie double.
compression is also handy for backups, but if you use ZFS or similar anyway it's not going to make a difference

Resident Evil: Extinction was ahead of the curve for 2007.
>Isaacs is told he's not allowed to appropriate resources to go chase Alice.

>He creates a voice profile from that recording.
>Uses text to speech to impersonate Wesker giving false orders.

What did the movie get wrong?
>Profile generation time was way too short.
That's... about it, though. Even the stilted delivery can be assumed to be pandering to the audience. Showing that the voice is fake. And the voice is reading along as he types, so we can assume the final recording will be smoother. I'm curious about earlier movies that might have featured this as a plot point.

The key distinction is that it can't be a magical voice changer. It has to follow scientific principles of machine learning voice generation, including training a profile on real voices.

With domain-driven design, how should I implement a domain model that depends on an service doing API calls in a Java/Spring Boot application?
All the examples I've seen use POJOs and local operations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91480303

The only difference between 
X < Y < Z
and 
X < Y and Y < Z
is that in the former Y is guaranteed to be evaluated once, while in the latter Y will be evaluated twice if the first comparison returns true.

If you disassemble a comparison with a function call f() in the middle of the chain you'll see that in the chained version the function is called once and then the result is duplicated on the stack to make it available for the 2nd comparison (since the first consumes it); while in the and version the function can be called twice so there's just a new load + CALL.

In your example doesn't make a difference but it seems that they kept this pattern. So the chained version loads the 2 once and then uses that DUP_TOP / ROT_THREE spam to duplicate it, while the and version just executes LOAD_CONST 2 twice which happens to be shorter.

>>91481561
>I'm asking in general.
DDD is anything but general, the whole point is to be specific for the domains used by the application

You're asking a question about a high-level architecture but all your details are focused on lower level implementation details.
Calling a service or API has barely any connection to the architecture. If the service/API is a huge driving point for the application you might put it in a separate domain and make a wrapper or facade for it to be more specific for your application, but you would still in the end just use the service in a specific domain (i.e. dice rolling)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
learning how to use OpenGL ES 2.0 since I bought an embedded linux board and there was a low-end GPU on it, so I figured I want to use how to use it
so far so good. using SDL to get the window and GL context (only SDL had support for Linux KMS/DRM so I don't even need X11/Wayland; and touch/motion/gesture support also looks good for touch screen displays)
so far learned to
- setup some skeleton project
- write basic solid-fill and texture-fill shaders
- transformation matrix for nice 2D rendering with pixel coordinates
- use stb_truetype to generate bitmaps and render text on screen
- fill triangles, parse .obj files, render model
- use depth testing/z-bufferding
- optimize loading with vertex buffers and index buffers
- the classic transformations: translate, scale, rotate, perspective
- UVN camera model

on my notebook it runs sub-1% CPU on 60hz, but on the embedded board (32-bit ARM 800Mhz dual-core) it eats 10% of CPU and I'm not sure is it can be optimized. sadly perf doesn't really work well on it to profile it.

well still many things ahead of me to learn. want to get some camera movement, covering objects with textures, maybe lighting? not planning physics simulation though, just renderer

Lisp is short for lisp processor, it's a recursive acronym
Ruby is short for Ruby Tuesday. It was named after the song Ruby Tuesday by the Rolling Stones. Yukihiro Matsumoto was a freeaboo, much like Hirohiko Araki, and he also frequented the restaurant Ruby Tuesday's.
Haskell was a name though up on the spot by Half Life fan Simon Jones. After playing the game in 1990, he decided to make a programming language equally as repellent to women.
Visual Basic is short for Visually Basic, as Bill Gates named it to subtlely mock the women that use it.
Python was not named after the snake, but after the Coney Island Rollercoaster named "The Python"

ITT, we discuss alternative operating systems and alternative ISA.

We discuss alternatives to Windows, Mac and Linux, such as SerenityOS, Haiku, GNU/HURD, AmigaOS/AROS, NT for PowerPC, and rare BSDs, as well homebrew projects and operating system development.
We also we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

You can also ask here for more information. Don't forget to check out the wiki, by the way!

>AIG Wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aig/_Alternative_ISA_General
>AOSG wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aosg/_Alternative_Operating_System_General

I've started writing an NT-like kernel. Won't be a clone, this isn't ReactOS (and anyway ReactOS is not the most true clone either.)
I might implement a small semblance of binary compatibility, enough for simplistic native mode or Win32 console programs to run, but not much more, and certainly not driver compatibility. It all depends on how much effort it would require.
I do envisage implementing basic Subsystem for Unix-like Applications, so I can run my GCC and programs like that. I will avoid annoying shit like signals as much as I can, I realise in practice they will probably become a necessity.
This will be a fun project. I wrote a Unix-like 3 years ago - it was about as feature-rich as Xv6, with a few simple programs ported like Ash shell. It was also as buggy as fuck because I didn't know what I was doing.
And since we're /aig/ too now apparently, I will even try to get this thing working on at least one non-x64 platform. Probably RISC-V or AArch64.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91475223
It's not that I love ARM
It's that I hate fans and any kind of noise, and love small, simple things. I like efficiency and tinkerability and neatness.

The idea of a small, silent box that does the simple things I actually use my computer for well and is unconcerned with anything else appeals to me on multiple levels.

Desktop computers are so ungainly and inelegant, laptops are generally noisy and restrictive, and are cumbersome in their own way. Things like the Raspberry Pi and other SBCs and kludgy devices like the Pinebook Pro and repurposed old media equipment like modded games consoles or hacked TV streaming sticks are just inherently appealing to me

X86_64 is a bloated, dying leviathan at this point, RISC is the future, Apple Silicon and the various ARM microprocessors powering Android and SBCs point the way, but its not there yet in non walled garden personal computing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91475468
I can get that. I hate fans too and I have a big suspicion sleeping in my younger years in a room with a very fan-y computer is what gave me tinnitus.

I got a Node202 and put a Core i5-13500 into it. Noctua fan. I literally have to hold my ear to the exhaust to hear it in normal operation and that fucker is faster than I need. I bought a small monitor (about Macbook Air size and same resolution/picture quality) and placed it on top of it. Like a Classical desktop computer. I sit in front of it like in the days of old. Getting to this setup was way more expensive than I'm willing to admit, but it was possible. I wasted a lot of money and time on utterly unsatisfying ARM computers before that.

Otherwise you could look into a convertible 2-in-1, (basically x86 tablets) remove the (usually shitty) keyboard, put it on a small tablet stand with additional usb hub and put a nicer, proper keyboard in front of it. Get a more recent one with a core i5 kaby lake and not only will it be fanless, it'll also run circles around any ARM SBC you can get while being cheaper and maybe even using less power than aformentioned ARM.

I can guarantee you any permutation of these options will make you happier than any ARM ever will. It's up to you to tinker and do research to find out what's best for you. Don't be afraid of unconventional solutions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91482116
torrents are split into many small chunks, which are shared between peers in an opportunistic way, this means pieces of files come in out of order, like putting together a jigsaw puzzle by place pieces randomly where they're meant to go
sequential download on the other hand constrains the client to only request pieces in order from start to finish, this results in less efficient download and uploading, and is a burden on the swarm, but it allows for certain kinds of files to be usable almost immediately, such as video files or music, as they often don't require later parts of the file to play the start, and as they play, they read from the file in order from the beginning, it's no different to say, watching youtube, and it downloads a bit ahead of where you're playing (caching), only the cache is going to a file on your disk to keep as well
if you don't need to use a file before it finishes downloading, then you will want to keep it turned off, as it will be faster without it

posts.com:
>>91474088
Most of these academic violations across all universities exist at the introductory CS level. There are a few reasons why this is the case:

1. Professors re-use assignments, allowing students to get code from others who have already taken the course. This re-use is usually not due to neglect; it takes a tremendous amount of work to create a well-crafted, bug-free, and bulletproof assignment write-up. Re-using this work is a necessity to ensure a high-quality course.

2. Collaboration policies are frequently vague. In introductory CS, the line between "don't share your code" and "talk about high-level algorithmic concepts" is extremely blurry. Most cases of academic dishonesty are not ultra-blatant cheating rings but cases that straddle this line. They usually represent instances where students are not (completely) aware that what they are sharing is a violation of the course policies.

3. Introductory CS course enrollments are at an all-time high across the board. More students in the classroom means less time for personalized instructions and feedback where these fuzzy cases of academic dishonesty can be addressed and discharged in a reasonable manner where learning occurs (instead of discipline).

That being said, the tools to catch code plagiarism are fairly robust and reliable (and free to use, at least in the case of the tool I'm thinking of). My colleagues and I have conjectured that the robustness of our tools is actually the reason that computer science has inflated plagiarism rates. Other disciplines likely encounter the same levels of academic dishonesty, but they don't have the means to detect such instances at the level that we can.

EDIT: be aware, there's a lot of painful misinformation in this thread about what instructors do and why they do it with respect to assignments and plagiarism. If anyone has any specific questions about CS instruction, I'm happy to answer them here or privately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Actual Silicon Valley UI/UX designer (and started as full stack SWE so I know literally everything) here. This is what you need to know

1. Read Design of Everyday Things by Don Norman
2. Everyone is a retard. This includes your C suite, every single product manager/BS nontechnical role, every pure SWE, and all of your users. They think a UI is basically a static image, they think a Figma mockup is 99% of the work, and they think most of UI is what the UI looks like
3. What your UI looks like is almost completely irrelevant. You can change it in 3 minutes in your CSS files if you programmed it properly. The function is all that actually matters. Steve Jobs was probably the only nontechnical SV guy to ever understand this and it basically turned him into a god.
4. UIs exist to solve problems. If you ask your users what their problems are, they instead will tell you their solutions. There solutions are shit which is why they have problems to begin with. You need to understand their problem. You cannot do this without domain expertise or without working with someone that has it. This is the primary reason why most UI/UX is trash, companies grow large enough to have pure UI/UX roles that silo off from what is actually going on, and the only people that can influence their team are the retards above.

Due to all of the above, it's very easy to find yourself in a position where you are getting nothing but bad feedback and suggestions from morons. To remedy this, the first thing I do on any project is write a set of very clear design rules. If someone suggests something that violates the rules, I explain the rule and why it exists, and say if they can come up with a data driven reason to adjust the rule I will do it, but you absolutely need to stay away from arguments about whitespace, making things "pop" etc., that is the death of most projects.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ht-f2QH4KE4

>>91478399
As another fellow UXer (UX researcher in my case) I can confirm this guys knows what he's talking about.

I can give a few more book recommendations:
The Inmates are running the asylum
About Face 4.0 or whatever version they're up to
Don't make me think by Steve Krug
Usability Engineering by Jakob Nielsen

The last one is honestly the best to make you shift your mindset. UX design is NOT about making a mock-up for a spec someone else wrote. It's about figuring out what the user's problem ACTUALLY is, solving it with a good workflow and usable UI, and THEN writing your specification. You almost always get it wrong the first time, so a big part is testing your solution prior to coding and shipping it. Since human brains work on irrational psychology you cannot just ask people what they think, you have to do your testing in a really roundabout way by simulating real-world scenarios and being extremely careful with how you word your questions (which is what I'm trained to do).

>>91473787
Yes, this is just your lack of expérience in UI/UX talking. Just like with programming you have to define the specifications before starting your design. You have to understand who is the audience, what does the company offer, what message it wants to send, and using which tone. Based on these prerequisites, you can now choose the color palette that highlights these concepts the best, the fonts, the level of density of content in a screen, the level of sharpness of the borders, etc... Then you can start designing your reusable components.

That's phase one. Phase two is to have a tree/graph of the data you want to display and interactions you want to have and to know what you want to highlight and to think about the users journey through your app to make the navigation intuitive. Then you can start building your actual UI.

That's just an over simplification and i'm just scratching the surface but if you have a large enough project and you start writing your UI without putting any thought into it, your UX will inevitably end up being at least mediocre.

For me, an example of good UX driven UI would be something like Supabase's Admin UI, the GSuite (even better than office in terms of usability) or Figma. A horrible example would be Uber's landing page. A good counter example would be rbnb's website.

say you are batching API calls. instead of using a for loop to await each promise you can instead create an array of functions that call the API and use Promise.All or Promise.AllSettled to await the entire batch so that you are either awaiting for all resovled, one reject, or all resolved or rejected. There Is a reason JS is Async.

>>91468937
I'll bite.
The adopted SPA model is horrible for performance and is the main reason why people complain about web browsers being slow and eating tons of RAM.
>visit page
>download 4MB (gzipped, unpacked is ~11MB) of JS
>browser parses it
>only now does the page actually start showing up
>CSR and hydration all happens, slowing things down to a crawl
>wait like 8s
>you can now use the site fully
All SPA websites have dogshit pagespeed/lighthouse/gtmetrix scores and its for this reason - devs keep stuffing in more JS. Whether it's libraries from npm or new features, they just cannot contain themselves from exposing the entire app behavior on first load instead of streaming only the bare minimum necessary content for current functioning.
On top of that add very poor quality code without any use of data structures or thought put into it, with the devs being deluded that their language has zero-cost abstractions for things like .forEach and .map and you have... The performance of MS Teams!
Also because of this model and separation "frontend" and backend devs are in a constant back-and-forth during development and it's from this chimp dev model "solutions" like GraphQL, gRPC and more have spawned, but the developer experience is a story for another day.

Google's Wiz, Ebay's Marko and Qwik attempt to address it by precaching (via a ServiceWorker) only the JS needed for the potential next immediate interactions and only actually parsing/executing it when that interaction occurs.

Also, it's a fucking comedy that it's more error prone than other languages without Typescript. Which itself is a fucking joke. Return types, Enums, there's so many borderline retarded decisions and behaviors.
There's so much more to complain about, but alas, word limit.

Brainlet detected who never had a real job kek. Here's an example for you retard:

TS:
type Person = {
  name: string;
  age: number;
  address: {
    street: string;
    city: string;
  };
};

function printPerson({ name, age, address: { street, city } }: Person) {
  console.log(`${name} is ${age} years old and lives at ${street}, ${city}.`);
}


JS:
function printPerson(person) {
  const { name, age, address } = person;
  const { street, city } = address;
  console.log(`${name} is ${age} years old and lives at ${street}, ${city}.`);
}


This is a very babby-tier example where you just have one nested level of properties. Now imagine a much more complex and constantly changing type, and trying to refactor it because the API endpoint changed kek. In typescript you can do this with one-two lines of extra code and some keyboard shortcuts. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP here

I use it for many things. Here are only a few.

1. Write cover letters for employers (I'm freelance). I paste the body of a job listings directly, and tell him "Write a reply to this"
2. Write small snippets of code, that I could probably write myself, but instead of wasting 15 minutes, I waste 1 minute.
3. I like studying languages. If I make a mistake, and I don't understand why, it explains really well the grammatical rules (yes, it can speak other languages)
4. When working with libraries or frameworks that are new to me, it can give me solutions without me having to browse endless pages of documentation
5. Code refactor. It is pretty good at analyzing code, and detecting pitfalls that, even though they might seem obvious, are easy to fly under the radar when working on a project for weeks
6. General trivia

These are just a few. As you can see from the list... what does ChatGPT do for me? Basically everything that I can already do by myself, but faster. It increased my productivity. The days that I could not use it, I felt like I was working with one hand tied to my back. I got used to new levels of productivity really fast. I can't live without them now.

I know I am probably helping to train the technology that is going to replace me in 5 years... but that is going to happen anyway, so I might as well let it help me now.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91460212
It's either your earphones breaking or it's just a mix of physiological and psychological issues. This happens to me too, sometimes I'll notice super sharp sibilance and things like the cymbals in songs that I was fine with before and get pissed off. Then after a day or two it'll "go away" -- and then start up again weeks or months later. There's a very large range of reasons why it could happen, from being tired, blood pressure, ear wax etc etc but what I'd suggest is to just stop thinking about it. Once you start hyper-fixating on it it'll just get worse because you're expecting it, waiting for it, which in turn makes your brain look for and focus on the sharper sounds.
Though out of curiosity, what's your tinnitus situation like? I've got mildly severe tinnitus in both ears so I suspect that might also have something to do with it.

Impossible to tell without a calibrated mic, people saying "I listen at 80dB" are just pulling it out of their ass. A rough way to calculate it is to get the output voltage of your DAC, set its volume to max, get the sensitivity of your IEMs, listen to a track with known dynamic range, adjust the volume in equalizer apo to know precisely how many dB you reduced the volume by. The average SPL is then sensitivity*voltage - volume - dynamic range/2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a typical motte-and-bailey, a rhetorical trick very frequently used by the woke mob. The point is to use academic-sounding language that sounds precise but is actually vague on purpose. When challenged, you use a very narrow interpretation that's easy to defend. When the challenge ends, you use a very broad interpretation that you can't defend but which is useful for your ideology. If someone points out the inconsistency, you can just patronizingly say that it's a subtle "technical term" that he "doesn't understand". In the case of race:
Motte (the easy to defend position): The division of people into races is fuzzy, and the boundaries could in principle be drawn differently. For example, it's only a matter of definition how many races there are or what's the race of a child of a black man and white woman.
Bailey (the false position that these people want to be true): The concept of genetically different human populations is meaningless. There are no significant differences aside from skin color.

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro

>Education/Workstation/Enterprise

W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

#!/usr/bin/env python
#
# requires: python-qbittorrent-api

import qbittorrentapi
import sys

user = "admin"
password = "adminadmin"
host = "10.0.0.5:8080"

qbt = qbittorrentapi.Client(host=host, username=user, password=password)
qbt.auth_log_in()

if not qbt.is_logged_in:
    print("not logged in", file=sys.stderr)
    exit(1)

fails = 0
for torrent in sys.argv[1:]:
    if qbt.torrents_add(torrent) == "Fails.":
        fails = fails + 1
        print("failed adding " + torrent, file=sys.stderr)

exit(fails)

Thinking in terms of theory it would be a security issue if a container without network capability could spawn a process (in-container) with network capability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91474262
Browser's can do this with XDG portals. Really file manager's should be using those portal's instead of spawning executables directly. This way you can confine your file manager and it can still spawn other executables outside. Assuming it has access to Dbus anyway then this is not a security vulnerability.

I question why one would want to prevent their file manager from accessing the network in the first place though. Do they not use network shares?

No. You don't "need" headphones or any of the electronics that support them.

Honorable mentions:

• DCA Stealth (neutral V) - $4000

Recommended open back headphones:
• Philips Fidelio X2 (bright V) - $160
• Senn HD 560S (neutral treble, flat bass) - $150
• DT 900 PRO X (bright, flat bass) - $250
Honorable mentions:
• Superlux HD668B/681 (bright V, chinkshit) - $35

• A good headphone paired with a mic
• Beyer MMX 300 (bright V, same as DT 770) - $230
Honorable mentions:
• HyperX Cloud II (bright V) - $80
• CM MH751/752 (neutral V) - $75

• Topping DX1 - $100

>>91418586
An Apple dongle with a USB-A adapter gets all its power from the USB port, so if it's particularly noisy you'll still hear screeching through that. Test with your CPU and especially GPU under load too.
If there's no screeching and it gets loud enough, there's no real reason to use anything more expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91455486
In short, no. It's a complicated subject but know that headphones are mostly minimum-phase and frequency response at the eardrum fully describes how something will sound, which means the time domain is irrelevant and reflections/reverb won't aid spatiality, which has been wrongly called soundstage. Soundstage actually references out-of-head localization, a literal sound stage, which happens with speakers(or any IRL sound) because of something called interaural time difference, which how sound reaches one ear before the other and interaural intensity difference, which is how the head shadow will lower the amplitude of frequencies as this happens. Also the shape of the head, mostly the outer ear, changes the frequency response of sound and gives directionality cues, without accounting for these factors constant out-of-head localization with headphones is not possible. The headstage will be 2D with only the information in the recording giving a sense of depth and location. There are some tricks to make people think something sounds more open without actually changing the sound of the headphones, like if you increase the driver distance, make the pads larger, or open the back volume to increase the audibility of external sounds.

Resolution is another thing wrongly attributed to something other than frequency response when in reality it's the higher amplitude of certain frequencies which leads to something sounding more detailed. I find the 5-10 kHz range is where this is most apparent since it can be masked by the upper midrange/treble peak if not done right.

>>91461008
Dumb argument. The headphone virtualization method has been well proven, see the Harman studies, it's not opinion that EQ works and you can make two different headphones sound the same. You don't need a measurement rig to do so, you just need to use AutoEQ and then adjust it from there to account for unit variance, fitment variance, and HRTF, assuming it meets the EQableness criteria specified above. That is completely separate from the idea that two headphones cannot possibly sound the same even if they produced the same frequency response at the eardrum, which is a claim you made that lacks any evidence and would require measurements, then blind testing to prove there is something that is currently immeasurable, likely outside the realm of physics because we have a pretty good idea what pressure waves are.

>Does Bluetooth have any downsides in mic or audio quality?
Yes, A2DP has no usable duplex modes. Either you have okay-ish (but with quite significant ~200ms latency) audio output or you have absolutely horrid mono duplex audio with HSP/HDP.
Either get a headset with its own proprietary dongle or just get one of these phone USB-C DACs (e.g. Samsung, Google or Apple ones should be usable).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91469675
I'm just a single Engineer with some experience doing technical interviews so take my advice with a grain of salt, but personally, I'd trim down the "resume words" like "contributed" and "enabling." Maybe it's just me, but they're invitations for the reader to zone out before they get to the actual technical descriptions that describe your specific experience/expertise. You have a technical resume with technical qualifications, no need to soften it.

>Worked in an Industrial IoT environment which remotely managed a connected network of industrial devices.
>Worked with clients to create and modernize sensor grids using a PaaS platform, providing live telemetry dashboards, digital twins, cloud-to-device operations, operator defined alarms and notification rules.

>Do I need to be more specific on what kind of tools, languages, services and other stuff that I used?
I would list them separately at the bottom as a "technology worked with" kind of addendum. The technical interviewers will be interested in what specific technology you work with, but it doesn't need to be part of the narrative of what you do/did at your job.

I posted here a while back about trying to find a job after about a year as a Data Analyst and almost nothing to show for it, and managed to find a new one as an Associate Business Analyst for 3 months temp-to-hire. It took about 6 or 7 months of searching and one really good interview.

I got some advice from a guy about 20 years older than me: When asked "how do you handle a challenging problem that represents a roadblock" and the answer was just "Check documentation -> Check prior similar work -> Google it -> Ask a Coworker -> Ask the Manager". This should have been obvious but I think the takeaway here is that unless you're some shining genius, just go for generic but confident answers on common questions, and not waffling on questions when you don't know or only have training as an answer.

I've been testing these two:

8Bit Do Ultimate 2.4G Controller (Not the Switch one with all effect joysticks)

Now this is a frankenstein controller. Basically the Switch Pro Controller Shape, With Xbox Layout AND PS4 like bumpers/triggers).

Works great with Steam Deck and PC, Battery last for hours, really like the dock/dongle combo. D-Pad is fine, not a big platformer Guy, I know some people like their D-pad in a certain way. It feels nice tho.

Baseus 65w Gan Charger with an extra EU Plug.

Works nicely, again mainly for Steam Deck. My only annoyance is that both USB-C Support 65w Charging. However the first port is connected to the Dock itself, while Port 2 is a 3m long USB-C Cable. HOWEVER because port 1 is plugged in, Port 2 only support 20w maximum. If I disconnect the dock it supports the 65w out on port 2(45 for the Steam Deck) but its pretty annoying

>>91470106
There are two Ultimate controller variants.

The 2.4g version and the Bluetooth version.

The 2.4g has an Xbox Style layout. That version has 2.4g AND bluetooth however that only works in D-input (For Android phones mainly and PC)

The Bluetooth version is Switch Style layout with Hall Effect joysticks. It still has 2.4g, X-Input but it also connects to the Switch as well.

2.4g is usually 50 dollars on Ali, the Bluetooth one is 65-70

>>91471988
Usually on Aliexpress its either "Bluetooth" or "2.4G" version. The Bluetooth is the more expensive one and works with Switch. 2.4g has Bluetooth as well but doesnt work with Switch, it has X-input instead

The two version looks the same, the 2.4G comes with 3 colors: Black White and Pink while the Switch Version comes only in black and white.

Also, the only way to physically differentiate them is that on the XBAY buttons are in black and white (and also in Nintendo Layout) while on the 2.4g they are Xbox Layout and Color

Bing's AI is clearly more geared toward using search results to get answers, rather than synthesizing them off a learned language model, and therefore should be able to answer up to date questions about tech, science, and also news and politics.

I'm initialising a component that makes a GET request with fetch.
When I wrap the fetch request in a useEffect() hook with an empty dependancy array fetch runs once when the component is initialised, as expected.
When I don't wrap the fetch request in a useEffect() hook, the request just fires endlessly.
Any reason for this? I'm sending a req.end() on the backend. I can't understand whats causing the loop, or a re-render of the component.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91463810

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91463793
Let me guess, you're setting state after receiving the response? You most likely do, and that state setter function call triggers a re-render, which in turn causes yet another fetch request to be made. Solution: put your fetch call in a useEffect with an empty dep array, or preferably use a fetching lib use-swr or rtkq.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91463793
React re renders a component whenever any props or state associated with the component changes. You get a fetch request, you get your response. and then you call setState which changes the state which causes a re-render which again fires off that fetch request. useEffect is used to counteract this. I believe you're very new to react.
I highly ask you to go through the beta.reactjs.org docs once. Because it'll teach you most of the stuff you need to know, rather than going through bloated tutorials. You can still do tutorials but get into the habit of reading documentation. When you join companies nobody will be making youtube videos/tutorials for the specific niche case you want to implement. React is fun once you learn how to handle the footguns it provides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91463845
>>91463960
Yes, originally I was updating the state with the fetch response which of course caused the infinite loop. Solved this by using a second state outside of the loop. I was trying to figure out why you would use a useEffect hook with the state as the dependancy array.
Didn't know that a state change caused a re-render (lol).
I'm just building as I go without a set tutorial but I should probably dive into a basic understanding of hooks like you said. Cheers

posts.name: Anonymous

Yeah, here's one: strings are utter garbage.
In JS they're internally encoded in UTF-16, so that's 2 * 4 * ceil(7 / 3) = 24 bytes = 192 bits to store something that could be represented using only 42 bits. And that's not including the length field and/or terminating null character, so in fact strings are even shittier than I make them out to be.

>>91465406
UUID is supposed to be 16 bytes, so other systems won't accept your 7 byte string. The point of a UUID is to be universally unique. So you can guarantee it's not used anywhere on AWS etc. If you don't need that property then just use an auto incrementing number since it'll be faster.

>>91467093
You can write your own serverless functions in Node, Go or whatever language/runtime you want and use them with supabase. The main difference will be that you don't call supabase.invoke or supabase.rpc, you'll have to make your own fetch calls to your endpoints using supabase-js. You can deploy the serverless functions wherever you want. I use a serverless function to catch the auth token from supabase and turn it into an http-only cookie before sending it to the client so that it can't be accessed from client side scripts (i use the jwt as a data transfer mechanism for segregated authz). So with to exceed the netlify or vercel free tier with such a trivial use of serverless functions, i'd need to make tens to hundreds of millions of authentication requests per month. For my main services, i prefer to have dockerized apis that run on VPSes.

>>91467245
I didn't fully understand what you meant by:
> This is what I'm talking about. I basically want to build my API locally and then possibly even deploy them without changing around endpoint urls in other places.

But about serverless functions, just beware of what you deploy on the edge. If you have a local database with no globalized access, deploying on the edge will actually increase the latency. Your static site & functions are very close to your users, yes, but if your database doesn't follow the same pattern of distribution, what happens is that the roadtrip between your serverless function and your db (request + response) nullifies any advantage involved in running your app on the edge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91467427
I have a general guideline when it comes to serverless. If it's a middleware or some computing that doesn't involve a db call, serverless is good. If you're using a globally distributed database like dynamodb or cosmosdb, it's great to make your entire api serverless. However, if you're having a local database you're better off having your api as close as possible to your db server and use serverless functions only for middleware or computing tasks that don't involve database calls. The worst possible network latency you can have would be 300 to 400ms (that's the exception, not the norm). The network latency between LA & Sidney is between 40 to 50ms. That's trivial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91468543
Well, the conventional architecture is x86 but there's a push for ARM in desktop and servers (ARM is already mainly used in mobiles). The mac computers that use m1 & m2 chips as well as the windows dev kit are ARM computers. ARM CPUs are cheaper, more power efficent and have less vulnerabilities. x86 CPUs use the CISC design and ARM uses RISC. However, ARM processors are limited in calculation capabilities compared to x86 and are not compatible with some x86 only programs. It shouldn't pose any problem for you if you use it to host your dockerized api.

Why are they so expensive compared to wireless mice?
Can I get a /g/ recommendation for one at reasonable price that's not shit?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91477760
Because headphone use more expensive tech than mice. It's more expensive to get sound to sound good than to have a working mouse. Also some headphones are like shoes, where you're paying for the brand name alone. It also takes a lot more to have long lasting battery life for headphones than for a mouse as headphones have more power draw.

In order to give you a proper recommendation we would have to know what you're using the headphones for and what you consider a reasonable price to be. My advice is to not take advice from /g/ or if you do, at least read product reviews before purchase.

My personal recommendation would likely not interest you as I'm not a soundfag. I prefer headphones that don't completely surround my ears like most quality headphones do. My favorite headphones are $20. One is a headphone jack and the other is USB. I also don't even bother with wireless as I am always right at my computer when I want to use the headphones.

posts.com:
Users of all levels welcome. Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>Which W10 version should I install?
Home/Pro: No, comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps.
Education/Workstation/Enterprise: Yes, but comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only): Yes, but comes with Win32 system utils, limited system apps like Settings and Notification area, no MS Store. If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something. If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

>Windows/Office install guide
https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>>91458012
So how do we prepare?
I saw a video of a guy who said something along the lines of:
>if you want to be ahead of the curve you need to understand that people won't be replaced by AI, but by people using the AI, so why not get in early and be the guy who replaces everyone with his early-adopter advantage?
Obviously this is limited by the fact that a billion other people had this same idea, and by the fact that you're also competing with colossal corporations who have the billions to make better tools, use them better than you, and even offer its services for free (by using monetization models that the average person can't afford).
But what else can we do?
Instead of being creative with music and trying to stand out with out artistic abilities, we're gonna have to get creative with out use of AI tools so that we can stand out even among those whose work is "augmented" by AI.

As Anon already said, the music market is already flooded with starving artists with amazing talent, so the final product isn't the whole ticket to success, but it's certainly an important part of it.
Now that we'll get tons of people in every single niche "making" better music than us, what will be the main factors influencing how one stands out? Is it gonna be all based on connections, image, social media presence, etc?
Because even if you can come up with a great new sound, people will just be able to describe it to a text-to-music model and get a pretty close emulation, so even fi you actually are unique, it's going to be harder to capitalize on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91458489
Marketing is a big component, but at least in electronic genres, if you make great music that stands out, it can be enough to put you on the map (or do the heavy lifting).
It's not all like in top-40 pop where it's next to impossible to make it without winning the popularity contest, so to speak.
But with good enough AI models being available to everyone with a web browser, the importance of the music itself will diminish, pushing all genres to a state that's closer to what we see in mainstream pop today.
But there's also the possibility that the tools won't be fully taken advantage of because most of those added "competitors" will just focus on what sells and not on being innovative (much like a lot of crazy sound design software remains obscure while most producers focus on the most mainstream VSTs).
It's going to be a gigantic change for sure, but we're still at its dawn, so it's hard to accurately predict how things will go, but it's still wise to try and at least predict the general direction things will go in, and figure out a course of action that minimizes the losses.

>>91458592
> if you make great music that stands out, it can be enough to put you on the map (or do the heavy lifting)
If Daft Punk secretly came back under the name “Grand Lollipop” and just uploaded their music online without any marketing effort, they would get 17 views on YouTube and maybe one comment: “sounds like Daft Punk but worse, NGMI”.

>with good enough AI models being available to everyone with a web browser
For the consumer, it wouldn’t be much different than listening to a random track on Spotify. And consumers don’t want random music in general.

Now, what makes you an artist is how hard you (or your label) make efforts to spread your music around: marketing, concerts, presence in social media, in traditional media, in nightclubs, in Spotify playlists, etc. Most people, and even most artists, don’t execute this effort properly because they lack know-how, money, connections and ultimately willpower (or their label doesn’t *really* believe in them, which has the same effect). So, they get nothing and remain obscure like X million other artists. And for the few who make it, it doesn’t matter if they used pre-made loops, their own talent, a ghost producer, or AI. No one cares and no one will care.

All the AI in the world won’t change the number of “slots” available to conquer the consumers’ attention, nor the number of artists ready to make real efforts to get noticed in this difficult business where the return on investment is very uncertain.

On the other hand, AI will kill people who just make background music and Fiverr musicians for sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Big labels aren't doing any magic shit you can't replicate as a bedroom producer nowadays. Those times are gone due to the internet. They are just using money and networking to get way faster towards their goals. It is pssoble, but it takes a lot of effort and time. As a bedroom producer without the heavy lifting of industry giants you are forced to slowly grow and cultivate your fanbase because you are forced to do shit on your own instead of outsourcing it.

You have to take care of your social media. Instead of a team of underpaid marketing guys fresh out of college.
You have to mix and master. Instead of sound engineers.
You have to organize your releases. Handle your finances. Graphic design. Merchandise...

Of course a lot of those things you could also outsource and pay somebody to design your logo, album cover, merchandise. Pay somebody to mix and master. And so on. But this is a risky investment because you can't be sure if it pays of in the end. If you handle most of the stuff on your own you able to monitor your progress and see what works and what fails.

>>91471104
You're smoothbraining. Most DAW's have the same workflow, just a few small differences in between (FL Studio has step sequencer, Ableton has automations automatically ready meanwhile you have to make automation clips with FL.) So if you learn one, you more or less learn them all. The general workflow is probably

>Make pattern
>Insert pattern on to playlist
>Make another pattern
>Insert on to playlist
>Add your special FX to get desired sounds
>Rinse and repeat til you have all your patterns made that lay out the length of the track
>Turn mix effects on
>Turn mix to mono after to determine volumes of mix
>Master with maximizer, light EQ probably


And that's it. This is more or less the same workflow all DAW's use, some of them excel in certain spots (FL Studio has incredible Midi notes system), some of them fall completely short (Automation clips and live recording still leave a lot to be desired in FL as opposed to Logic). If you can't follow this advice, you probably will never make music or produce anything.

>>91471540
The principle is still the same, whether you work with some midi, live audio recording, hybrid, or whatever it is. Recorded audio is still editing the timing to be right, doing the sound design, probably doubling the instrument with 25% l/r pan for harmonizing (either recorded or same clip pan left right with split second alteration to prevent phasing), and copy pasting on the DAW more or less. It is a consistent workflow across the board. Personally, Logic or Ableton are far better for what you want to do, because if you do use FX heavy, it's really easy to automate with both since they're both armed automatically to handle it.

I didn't say you can get famous by only posting something online and doing zero marketing. Just that it's not everything. If your music is good and unique and you send it to labels, sooner or later one of them will sign it and you can build from there with social media and whatnot.
If your music isn't good, no amount of marketing or artificial pushes will make you successful (see all the industry plant that have dream-level opportunities but just aren't making worthwile music and they disappear).

>For the consumer, it wouldn’t be much different than listening to a random track on Spotify. And consumers don’t want random music in general.
Yeah, but if you're currently competing with N people to get a stream/get signed/whatever, with the influx of new artists (and artists who previously sucked but now can put out better music), N becomes bigger, reducing your chances of getting that stream/contract/etc.

>Now, what makes you an artist is how hard you (or your label) make efforts to spread your music around: marketing, concerts, presence in social media, in traditional media, in nightclubs, in Spotify playlists, etc. Most people, and even most artists, don’t execute this effort properly because they lack know-how, money, connections and ultimately willpower (or their label doesn’t *really* believe in them, which has the same effect). So, they get nothing and remain obscure like X million other artists. And for the few who make it, it doesn’t matter if they used pre-made loops, their own talent, a ghost producer, or AI. No one cares and no one will care.
I don't disagree with this.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91464328
>All the AI in the world won’t change the number of “slots” available to conquer the consumers’ attention
True.

>nor the number of artists ready to make real efforts to get noticed in this difficult business where the return on investment is very uncertain.
Completely wrong.
Lots of people have knowledge in social media, marketing, and whatever's needed to succeed, but their music simply doesn't clear the bar for good enough, so people don't listen to them.
Now that all of those can get their music past that bar, the competition gets much harder for everybody.
In my original post that you're responding to, when I'm talking about competing, it's already implied that you have your marketing/branding/etc in order. It's a separate variable from the music itself, and success is a combination of both.
As you said, people with good music and no marketing will have a hard time being successful, but the same is true for people with good marketing and bad music. It's only people who have both that succeed, and this will turn all those people with good marketing and bad music into those good music + good marketing people, whom you'll be competing with.

Not to mention how you can use tools like ChatGPT to help you with marketing as well lmao, so those who have neither the music nor the marketing will still have access to good msuic and good marketing. We're completely fucked either way lmao.

2/2

PS: I'm using marketing here as the sum of everything on the "selling" side of the equation, which includes marketing itself, personal branding, logo, interviews, collabs, etc.

No. The technical difference is manual memory management. Its at the core of the machine. Stayed that way until machines started implementing out of order execution and branch prediction thats just a thorn on my side. What we need is a new mod of C for these new abominations, not a new language with niggerlicious syntax and complexity masking.

You make a safe implementation of something in C... Store it in a library or a macro. Use that library or macro next time. It builds up. People share libraries all the time... Open Source builds up. Something like folk stories but for computers

Waiting another 5-10 years for the optimizations to arrive and not using the working system now is foolish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91468121
There's benefits to tram line coming every 3 minute, but the benefit of Tesla cars is its instant ondemand without wait and can scale from 3 people per hour to 4000+ pph. With trains, you need a constant demand or else, if it falls to half, the train would need to be run at higher interval to maximize efficiency, if it falls below 1/4, then the wait time could increase a lot. The alternative is to design around lower PPH and hope that peaks/lows would balance each other to make economic sense, that also leads to packed trains/etc which can cause lot of deaths/injury/etc. The system Boring Tunnel solves is the dynamic demand curve, while also being able to maintain a high enough throughput during peaks.

The main problem with Eurotards trying to talk about public transit in the US is failure to comprehend the difference in space and population density here, and the subsequent increase in transit costs that incurs.

Look at say, Indiana. 73 people per square kilometer, somewhat concentrated in Indianapolis but otherwise spread evenly around the state. Compare to England which is 434 people per square kilometer with lots of very dense population centers and corridors. You probably live close to a dense hub and your destination is probably near one also. It's not like that in the United States. Say you live in Terra Haute and have relatives in Crawfordsville. The kind of hub-based public transit system you want would be utterly retarded. You'd spend all day waiting for the train to ride it 75 miles into the city and then waiting again to ride it 50 miles out to your destination. And that's assuming Crawfordsville is actually your destination and it's not actually some rural house another 10 miles away from the train station. It would be simultaneously expensive and unpleasant for everyone thanks to its pointless inefficiency.

Subways and passenger trains do exist in most of the places where it makes sense, and we have a government-subsidized passenger carrier (Amtrak). The only place Amtrak pays for itself is The Acela Express in the Northeast Corridor, which is not surprisingly the most densely populated part of the country with plenty of large hubs and dense suburbs.

posts.com:
Serious and simple answer: a monad is a type augmenter.

It's a thing that adds extra capabilities to a type, beyond what that type would ordinarily have. To use a C++ example, std::optional<T> is a monad. A std::optional<T> is basically a T, but with the added capability of having a "doesn't exist" state (distinct from null/0), which in most cases will be a capability the type T did not have before. The Haskell example of this (and probably the most commonly referred to one) is the Maybe monad.

I think when Haskell users try to explain monads they make it more complicated than it really is, possibly in an effort to appear smart by using terminology the reader isn't familiar with (wow, he used all these big fancy words! he must be really smart!). A monad, in programming, is just a type augmenter.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you ever programmed in functional language without monads, you would soon encounter so called "state passing style".
The syntax can get out of hand with it quickly.
Suddenly each function in your structural recursion functions accepts the state, and returns tuple of value and new state. And each caller needs to bind both, and pass the new state from there on.
Monads are really just a syntactic sugar for this. It makes the state, its passing and its re-binding implicit.
There are some operators to call functions outside of this monad (functions that don't work with this state), or how to combine various monads.
That's it. Academics are just really bad at communicating this.

you can define a monad with these operations:
>pure: wrap a value in the monad
>map: apply a function to every value in the monad
>join: flatten the top 2 layers of a nested monad into one
This definition is pretty handwavy. Some monads (like a->)don’t exactly “contain” values in the typical sense, and there are some additional laws that describe how these functions should be related. Still, it’s approximately right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91479247
Basically, but not quite. Dual band is dual radio, but dual radio doesnt need to be dual band. Some old devices dont support 5ghz or some various IEEE specifications. You don't usually have to think about this though. A lot of routers ship with both 2.4gz and 5ghz radios which are different bands, with openwrt you can program them to be different wireless connections with different names and different rules, a lot of proprietary software might be able to do this too though. Band = Ghz range, Radio = Transmitter. You could sell something with two 5ghz radios with one AC/AX/AD specification and one something else and call it dual radio though so I'd be careful thinking of it as the exact same thing if you have any (likely very) old machines that only support 2.4ghz, dual band generally refers to two different bands so 2.4/5ghz. For example I dont think the Nintendo Wii supports 5ghz, but the Wii U does. I think very few people would use wifi on a wii in 2023 though, and if you do (idk, streaming games from pc hdd? mkwii custom servers? i dont know) you probably use ethernet cable anyways...
Unless you have very old machines that you need internet for, don't worry about 2.4ghz...

posts.com:
Users of all levels welcome. Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>Which W10 version should I install?
Home/Pro: No, comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps.
Education/Workstation/Enterprise: Yes, but comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only): Yes, but comes with Win32 system utils, limited system apps like Settings and Notification area, no MS Store. If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something. If you know what you're doing:

https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>Useful programs for a new install
https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>I miss Windows 11 minus X
OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\MMC\{E12BBB5D-D59D-4E61-947A-301D25AE8C23}]
"Restrict_Run"=-

[HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\MMC\{8FC0B734-A0E1-11D1-A7D3-0000F87571E3}]
"Restrict_Run"=-
