posts.sub: Will Quantum Computing Bring a Cryptopocalypse?
posts.com:
https://www.securityweek.com/cyber-insights-2023-quantum-computing-and-the-coming-cryptopocalypse/

"The waiting time for general purpose quantum computers is getting shorter, but they are still probably decades away," notes Security Week.

But "The arrival of cryptanalytically-relevant quantum computers that will herald the cryptopocalypse will be much sooner — possibly less than a decade."
It is important to note that all PKI-encrypted data that has already been harvested by adversaries is already lost.

The one thing we can say with certainty is that it definitely won't happen in 2023 — probably. That probably comes from not knowing for certain what stage in the journey to quantum computing has been achieved by foreign nations or their intelligence agencies — and they're not likely to tell us.

"Quantum computing is not, yet, to the point of rendering conventional encryption useless, at least that we know of, but it is heading that way," comments Mike Parkin, senior technical engineer at Vulcan Cyber. Skip Sanzeri, co-founder and COO at QuSecure, warns that the threat to current encryption is not limited to quantum decryption. "New approaches are being developed promising the same post-quantum cybersecurity threats as a cryptographically relevant quantum computer, only much sooner," he said.

Steve Weston, co-founder and CTO at Incrypteon, offers a possible illustration. "Where is the threat in 2023 and beyond?" he asks. "Is it the threat from quantum computers, or is the bigger threat from AI? An analysis of cryptoanalysis and code breaking over the last 40 years shows how AI is used now, and will be more so in the future."

The article warns that "the coming cryptopocalypse requires organizations to transition from known quantum-vulnerable encryption (such as current PKI standards) to something that is at least quantum safe if not quantum secure."

"The only quantum secure cryptography known is the one-time pad."

>>91478128
>What is the actual state of gaming on Linux? Is it a bother or can I just run games instantly with wine?

What I personally use when gaming, is Steam. And they pretty well handle gaming on Linux. Some games are native (Crusader Kings 2, Europe Universalis 4, XCOM 2, etc), some runs trough Steam Proton compatibility tool (which is basically just version of Wine, which Steam have branched out).
If curious, can check are games you wishing to play supported on Proton.
https://www.protondb.com
Example with Stellaris
https://www.protondb.com/app/281990

Usually playing strategy games, and those are less demanding. So if you want to use some "shooter style" games, for those there might be some performance issues.

If you already have an Steam account, you can try to install linux on separate partion. Better on separate disk (less chance to fuck up main OS (windows), and test it out yourself. Linux Mint and Fedora was some popular newbie friendly linux distributions some years ago. Not sure which are best today.

t.occasionally gaming while using Fedora Linux for 8 years

>x220/x230

Those have sandy/ivy bridge CPUs that do not support AVX2, modern video codecs and have only 2 cores with 4 threads. They will sound like a jet engine if you try something as basic as watching a youtube video or launching a VSCode. They also have terrible 720p display, and while it can be upgraded to full hd display, it requires to to solder an adapter board to the main motherboard, which is not something that most people are willing to do. Not to mention that they do not have official windows 11 support and you will need to do a rufus workaround to install it. Their battery life is also mediocre, unless you will somehow get your hands on a slice battery, that are insanely expensive in 2023.

Yeah, disabling security features on your device is totally smartest thing to do.

Some work already being done on Toolformer: https://github.com/nathankot/bashi (very crude so far)

Toolformer summary according to GPT:
>In this paper, the authors show that language models can learn to use these smaller and simpler programs (called APIs) to help them solve problems more effectively. They created a new model called Toolformer that can decide which APIs to use, when to use them, and how to use the results to improve its language abilities. Toolformer can learn to use APIs by watching just a few examples, and can incorporate a variety of tools like calculators, search engines, and translation systems.
>The authors found that Toolformer can use APIs to improve its performance on many different tasks, without sacrificing its ability to use language effectively. This means that language models can combine their existing strengths with the benefits of external tools to become even more powerful problem solvers.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04761

Basically we are giving the first steps on LLM teaching themselves.

>how we could potentially create a large dataset for the Pyg.
We have text translation/summarization models available (e.g. BART).
https://huggingface.co/docs/transformers/model_doc/bart
A model like this could be trained on fictional text. The kicker is that the output of this model becomes dialogue.
For example:
Dorothy thinks for a moment. She is not sure where she is or who the wicked witch is.
Who are you? Dorothy asks.

... could become:
*Dorothy thinks for a moment. She is not sure where she is.* Who are you?

This would allow us use existing story datasets and convert them into role-play esque dialogue for training the Pyg.
For degenerates, this could be ran on that Literotica dataset or whatever that was used to create that Porn Story model.
>Story to Roleplay Model

god you are so retarded; do this with templates
pub fn OptionalMembers(comptime Type: type) type {
    const info = @typeInfo(Type);
    if (info != .Struct or info.Struct.is_tuple) {
        @compileError("Argument must be a struct.");
    }
    const old_fields = info.Struct.fields;
    comptime var fields: [old_fields.len]StructField = undefined;
    inline for (old_fields) |field, i| {
        const NewType = ?field.type;
        fields[i] = .{
            .name = field.name,
            .type = NewType,
            .default_value = null,
            .is_comptime = false,
            .alignment = @alignOf(NewType),
        };
    }
    comptime var info = std.builtin.Type{
        .Struct = .{
            .layout = .Auto,
            .backing_integer = null,
            .fields = &fields,
            .decls = &.{},
            .is_tuple = false,
        },
    };
    return @Type(info);
}

You are what I hate about /g/.

My dad was all about Linux and Ubuntu and thought Raspberry Pi was the coolest shit. I have no idea what that last one even is despite him showing me multiple videos on it. And I was able to install things from github onto his Linux computer easier than he could, despite me never having used Linux before. Great on Ubuntu for giving Linux a GUI. But fuck all this noncompatable shit. Getting his Windows games to run on Linux was a fucking nightmare.

I respect the Linux message, but it being independent also leads to just not having enough over a userbase to support itself for the common user. The common user doesn't need to take their computer back from Microsoft. They'll eat the updates and be happy. When you only use your computer for Facebook and Youtube, who gives a shit? The common user only gets pissed about it when Windows Update forces their computer to restart when they are in the middle of working. Windows has been getting worse and worse but at least things are compatible with it. Myself, I've been able to successfully stop Windows Updates and my computer is where I want it now.

Trying to get most programs to work on Linux was like pulling teeth. Meanwhile on Windows, I've only run into one program that was designed primarily for Linux, but they also made a version for Windows as well. All other programs I download work immediately. On Linux, if it isn't designed for Linux you're SOL. If it's designed for Windows, you might be able to make it compatible after spending hours on github and downloading a bunch of shit so it works.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91477413
And they'll be IP68, which is the highest IP rating. The first digit is for solids. The second digit is for water. IP6 is complete protection against dust. IP66 would be complete protection against dust and jets of water. You could leave it on the deck of a boat and it would be protected. The only thing that's going to get through IP68 is if you dropped your phone in water and as it descended, atmospheric pressure blew the seals out. If you had a keyboard with an atmosphere rating, it could survive up to X atm.
